articles.headline: What Happens When Your Insurer Goes Under?
articles.snippet: A sort of low-grade fear has set in among insurance policyholders. How can you protect yourself?
articles.abstract: A sort of low-grade fear has set in among insurance policyholders. How can you protect yourself?
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the problems at the American International Group burst into the consciousness of everyday consumers two months ago, a sort of low-grade fear has set in among policyholders at insurance companies of all kinds.

articles.headline: Facing Crisis, Congress Makes Sense
articles.snippet: At a House hearing, Barney Frank used a witness to send a strong message to the securitization industry.
articles.abstract: At a House hearing, Barney Frank used a witness to send a strong message to the securitization industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congress has an endless capacity to disappoint. A scandal erupts, and it rushes to pass legislation full of unintended consequences. Then, when no one is looking, it strips away regulations the country needs. Ideology too often trumps common sense. Partisanship too often gets in the way of practical solutions. It’s an old story, I know.

articles.headline: Packages You Won’t Need a Saw to Open
articles.snippet: Retailers are creating alternatives to infuriating “clamshell” packages and cruelly complex twist ties.
articles.abstract: Retailers are creating alternatives to infuriating “clamshell” packages and cruelly complex twist ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  A number of retailers and manufacturers have a gift for holiday shoppers: product packaging that will not result in lacerations and stab wounds.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Words Fly, but No Aid for Detroit
articles.snippet: The White House urged Congressional Democrats to speed up access to $25 billion in federal loan guarantees for ailing U.S. automakers.
articles.abstract: The White House urged Congressional Democrats to speed up access to $25 billion in federal loan guarantees for ailing U.S. automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House urged Congressional Democrats on Friday to speed up access to $25 billion in federal loan guarantees for the ailing automakers and accused the Democrats of “choosing a path that will only lead to partisan gridlock” by also insisting on tapping into the financial industry bailout fund to help the carmakers.

articles.headline: Employers Offer Workers Fewer Health Care Plans
articles.snippet: Many workers are finding that the buffet of options in their medical plans has been trimmed to a very short menu.
articles.abstract: Many workers are finding that the buffet of options in their medical plans has been trimmed to a very short menu.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s the annual “open enrollment” season in corporate America, when employees choose their medical plans for the coming year. But this time, even if they are fortunate enough to have a job at a company that still offers health benefits, many workers are finding that the buffet of options has been trimmed to a very short menu.

articles.headline: Spam Turns Serious and Hormel Turns Out More
articles.snippet: The canned meat product has become the emblematic food for hard times as consumers look for ways to stretch their grocery budgets.
articles.abstract: The canned meat product has become the emblematic food for hard times as consumers look for ways to stretch their grocery budgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Minn. — The economy is in tatters and, for millions of people, the future is uncertain. But for some employees at the Hormel Foods Corporation plant here, times have never been better. They are working at a furious pace and piling up all the overtime they want.

articles.headline: Automakers Offer Big Incentives to Spur Sales
articles.snippet: Automakers are offering cash rebates and dealers steep discounts to try to make room on lots for new models.
articles.abstract: Automakers are offering cash rebates and dealers steep discounts to try to make room on lots for new models.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — This is a miserable time to be selling cars, as the billions of dollars in losses gushing from the Detroit automakers show, but it may be the best opportunity ever to buy one.

articles.headline: In Transition, Ties to Lobbying
articles.snippet: Barack Obama has imposed strict conflict-of-interest restrictions, but there are dozens of former lobbyists on his transition team.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama has imposed strict conflict-of-interest restrictions, but there are dozens of former lobbyists on his transition team.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama has imposed stricter conflict-of-interest restrictions on his White House transition team than any president before him. But a list of transition team members that his office made public on Friday includes a complicated tangle of ties to private influence-seekers.

articles.headline: Tech Companies, Long Insulated, Now Feel Slump
articles.snippet: In the span of a few weeks, orders for technology products have collapsed and workers have been laid off.
articles.abstract: In the span of a few weeks, orders for technology products have collapsed and workers have been laid off.
articles.lead_paragraph: The technology industry, which resisted the economy’s growing weakness over the last year as customers kept buying laptops and iPhones, has finally succumbed to the slowdown.

articles.headline: Obama’s Talk With Clinton Starts Buzz
articles.snippet: For Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, there would be pros and cons to a partnership if she were secretary of state.
articles.abstract: For Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, there would be pros and cons to a partnership if she were secretary of state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The end of the presidential campaign seemed to signal the completion of the Obama-Clinton drama. But now it turns out there could be a surprise ending.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Mormons Tipped Scale in Ban on Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: Mormons played an extraordinary role in the passage of a California ballot measure that once seemed close to defeat.
articles.abstract: Mormons played an extraordinary role in the passage of a California ballot measure that once seemed close to defeat.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO  Less than two weeks before Election Day, the chief strategist behind a ballot measure outlawing same-sex marriage in California called an emergency meeting here.
articles.byline: By Jesse McKinley and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: Congo’s Riches, Looted by Renegade Troops
articles.snippet: The exploitation of a tin mine is emblematic of the deadly role that Congo’s natural wealth has played in its misery.
articles.abstract: The exploitation of a tin mine is emblematic of the deadly role that Congo’s natural wealth has played in its misery.
articles.lead_paragraph: BISIE, Congo — Deep in the forest, high on a ridge stripped bare of trees and vines, the colonel sat atop his mountain of ore. In track pants and a T-shirt, he needed no uniform to prove he was a soldier, no epaulets to reveal his rank. Everyone here knows that Col. Samy Matumo, commander of a renegade brigade of army troops that controls this mineral-rich territory, is the master of every hilltop as far as the eye can see.

articles.headline: At Army Base, Stork Landed With the Airborne
articles.snippet: There has been a sharp increase in births at Fort Bragg in North Carolina after the return of thousands of soldiers.
articles.abstract: There has been a sharp increase in births at Fort Bragg in North Carolina after the return of thousands of soldiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C.  Joanne Chavonne saw pregnant women everywhere in town, shopping at Target for diapers or dining at a Mexican restaurant.

articles.headline: At Exxon, Making the Case for Oil
articles.snippet: As the world begins to shun dirty fuels, an undaunted Exxon Mobil says oil will power economies for decades.
articles.abstract: As the world begins to shun dirty fuels, an undaunted Exxon Mobil says oil will power economies for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIX years of relentlessly rising prices have showered the oil industry with record profits even as whipsawing energy costs have left many Americans alternately furious and baffled.

articles.headline: When Citi Lost Sallie
articles.snippet: Sallie L. Krawcheck’s departure from Citigroup was not related to the glass ceiling but the result of an old-fashioned corporate bar brawl.
articles.abstract: Sallie L. Krawcheck’s departure from Citigroup was not related to the glass ceiling but the result of an old-fashioned corporate bar brawl.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON a Saturday in late September, at a corporate retreat at the Phoenician resort in Scottsdale, Ariz., Sallie L. Krawcheck gave a speech thanking her troops at Citigroup for their hard work, and then returned to her room.

articles.headline: A Rescue Plan Without Taxpayer Money
articles.snippet: There are many smart ideas floating around about how to solve the twin problems posed by securitizations and resetting mortgages.
articles.abstract: There are many smart ideas floating around about how to solve the twin problems posed by securitizations and resetting mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: HELLO, taxpayers. Worried about the fate of the $350 billion that the government has asked you to fork over so far to help rescue financiers from themselves?

articles.headline: Lose the BlackBerry? Yes He Can, Maybe
articles.snippet: Security concerns and record-keeping laws mean that Barack Obama is unlikely to become the first e-mailing president.
articles.abstract: Security concerns and record-keeping laws mean that Barack Obama is unlikely to become the first e-mailing president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Sorry, Mr. President. Please surrender your BlackBerry.

articles.headline: World Leaders Vow Joint Push to Aid Economy
articles.snippet: The leaders of 20 countries agreed to work more closely, but put off thornier questions until next year in an early challenge for the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: The leaders of 20 countries agreed to work more closely, but put off thornier questions until next year in an early challenge for the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing the gravest economic crisis in decades, the leaders of 20 countries agreed Saturday to work together to revive their economies, but they put off thornier decisions about how to overhaul financial regulations until next year, providing a serious early challenge for the Obama administration.

articles.headline: Downturn Drags More Consumers Into Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: With their credit cards drained, the latest bankruptcy filers are deeper in debt than those in previous downturns.
articles.abstract: With their credit cards drained, the latest bankruptcy filers are deeper in debt than those in previous downturns.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy’s deep troubles are pushing a growing number of already struggling consumers into bankruptcy, often with far more debt than those who filed in previous downturns.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Pact, Approved in Iraq, Sets Time for U.S. Pullout
articles.snippet: Iraq’s cabinet approved a security agreement that calls for a full withdrawal of American troops from the country by the end of 2011.
articles.abstract: Iraq’s cabinet approved a security agreement that calls for a full withdrawal of American troops from the country by the end of 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s cabinet on Sunday overwhelmingly approved a proposed security agreement that calls for a full withdrawal of American forces from the country by the end of 2011. The cabinet’s decision brings a final date for the departure of American troops a significant step closer after more than five and a half years of war.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Stephen Farrell

articles.headline: Rather’s Lawsuit Shows Role of G.O.P. in Inquiry
articles.snippet: Dan Rather’s lawsuit seems to have unearthed evidence of political influence in an internal CBS investigation.
articles.abstract: Dan Rather’s lawsuit seems to have unearthed evidence of political influence in an internal CBS investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Dan Rather filed suit against CBS 14 months ago  claiming, among other things, that his former employer had commissioned a politically biased investigation into his work on a “60 Minutes” segment about President Bush’s National Guard service  the network predicted the quick and favorable dismissal of the case, which it derided as “old news.”

articles.headline: Newspapers Jettisoning Top Talent to Cut Costs
articles.snippet: Circuit City fired its best employees and is now in bankruptcy. Are newspapers following the same path?
articles.abstract: Circuit City fired its best employees and is now in bankruptcy. Are newspapers following the same path?
articles.lead_paragraph: In March 2007, Circuit City came up with a plan to confront softening sales and competition from online and offline retailers: fire the most talented, experienced employees.

articles.headline: Facing Deficits, States Get Out Sharper Knives
articles.snippet: Rising unemployment and sharp drops in tax revenue are forcing states to face service cuts, hiring freezes, tax increases, or all of these.
articles.abstract: Rising unemployment and sharp drops in tax revenue are forcing states to face service cuts, hiring freezes, tax increases, or all of these.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Two short months ago lawmakers in California struggled to close a $15 billion hole in the state budget. It was among the biggest deficits in state history. Now the state faces an additional $11 billion shortfall and may be unable to pay its bills this spring.

articles.headline: No Bonuses for 7 Senior Executives at Goldman
articles.snippet: The decision, requested by the bank’s executives, is likely to put heavy pressure on Goldman Sachs’s competitors to take similar action.
articles.abstract: The decision, requested by the bank’s executives, is likely to put heavy pressure on Goldman Sachs’s competitors to take similar action.
articles.lead_paragraph: As public scrutiny of Wall Street pay intensifies, one bank has already decided what it will award in bonuses to its top seven executives this year: nothing.

articles.headline: If Detroit Falls, Foreign Makers Could Be Buffer
articles.snippet: Experts say the foreign carmakers could take control of the industry and its supplier network more quickly than is understood.
articles.abstract: Experts say the foreign carmakers could take control of the industry and its supplier network more quickly than is understood.
articles.lead_paragraph: The failure of one or more of Detroit’s Big Three automakers would put a huge initial dent in American manufacturing, but in time foreign car companies would pick up the slack by stepping up production in their plants here, many industry experts and economists say.

articles.headline: For More of Mexico’s Wealthy, Cost of Living Includes Guards
articles.snippet: As drug-related violence spirals out of control, security measures have become a way of life for Mexico’s affluent.
articles.abstract: As drug-related violence spirals out of control, security measures have become a way of life for Mexico’s affluent.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  When José hops into his Ferrari, presses his Ferragamo loafer to the floor and fills the night air with a deep roar, his bodyguards hustle into a black sport utility vehicle with their weapons at the ready, tailing their fast-moving boss through the streets.

articles.headline: Clinton Vetting Includes Look at Mr. Clinton
articles.snippet: An examination of Bill Clinton by Obama aides suggests that his wife is a serious possibility as secretary of state.
articles.abstract: An examination of Bill Clinton by Obama aides suggests that his wife is a serious possibility as secretary of state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Barack Obama’s advisers have begun reviewing former President Bill Clinton’s finances and activities to see whether they would preclude the appointment of his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, as secretary of state, Democrats close to the situation said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Seeking Aid, Automakers Have a Friend in the U.A.W.
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers president will testify to Congress this week, but many lawmakers may say that unions have exacerbated Detroit’s problems.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers president will testify to Congress this week, but many lawmakers may say that unions have exacerbated Detroit’s problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  When Ron Gettelfinger, president of the United Automobile Workers union, appears this week at Congressional hearings to help make the case for the Detroit automakers getting emergency federal aid, he wants lawmakers to know what he believes is at stake.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Deregulator Looks Back, Unswayed
articles.snippet: Phil Gramm pushed laws that he says unshackled businesses from restraints but critics say contributed to the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Phil Gramm pushed laws that he says unshackled businesses from restraints but critics say contributed to the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Back in 1950 in Columbus, Ga., a young nurse working double shifts to support her three children and disabled husband managed to buy a modest bungalow on a street called Dogwood Avenue.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: A Studio, a Star, a Fateful Bet
articles.snippet: “Valkyrie” was conceived as a dramatic showcase for Tom Cruise, as well as a high-profile effort to kick-start United Artists.
articles.abstract: “Valkyrie” was conceived as a dramatic showcase for Tom Cruise, as well as a high-profile effort to kick-start United Artists.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  If there was a nervous moment at Friday night’s showing here of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer’s new James Bond movie, “Quantum of Solace,” it came with a trailer for the studio’s next big bet: “Valkyrie,” in which Tom Cruise plays a German officer who tried to kill Hitler.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: At National Review, a Threat to Its Reputation for Erudition
articles.snippet: The magazine faces the twin challenges of re-energizing the conservative movement while trying to stay relevant.
articles.abstract: The magazine faces the twin challenges of re-energizing the conservative movement while trying to stay relevant.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a span of 252 days, the National Review lost two Buckleys  one to death, another to resignation  and an election.

articles.headline: Citigroup Plans to Sell Assets and Cut More Jobs
articles.snippet: The banking giant announced Monday that it would cut another 24,000 jobs, bringing its total reductions in the coming months to 52,000.
articles.abstract: The banking giant announced Monday that it would cut another 24,000 jobs, bringing its total reductions in the coming months to 52,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: With its losses mounting, Wall Street is cutting jobs faster  and deeper  than even pessimists had feared.
